note:
The body of the request overwrites the document in the collection which drops
out 'nom_freq' This is not the right way to update a single element.
Trying to add 'nom_freq' back in doesn't work, it again overwrites the document.
So this is what we have now in 'feeders'.

Shows documents available in the `test_site_controller` collection. This will show 'request DOES NOT get expected response' because the '_id's will be different in each test run. You can visually compare the response expected with the response received and see that the id itself is the only difference.
Deleted 'assets', one of two collections in test_site_controller.
Adds 'assets' back in so there are two again for testing.

A DEL always deletes a whole document - even if you've
specified some element within it. Specifying an element within a document
is useful for versioning but is moot in the initial release. It is not clear
to me at the moment if passing a value in the body violates DEL convention.
If not in the body, we could pass a value in whatever manner we use for GETs.
At present, any body is ignored in a DEL request.
Adds another collection so there are two again.
Deletes all the collections in test_site_controller
Creates a new entry so we can update a single element correctly.
This is the correct way to update a single element in the document.
Creates a large object to traverse.
Changes a deeply nested value - traversing objects only.
Creates another object with arrays in it so we can traverse it.
Changes a deeply nested value - traversing both objects and arrays.
